Specific Details: Policy on e-cigarettes
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Policy on e-cigarettes
Intended Results: Request a meeting to discuss the potential role of e-cigarettes in achieving Tobacco Free Ireland's objective of reducing smoking rates, the need for policy by the DoH and for a debate in the Dail on the topic.::Highlight key conclusions of the 'State of Tobacco Control in Ireland' report by the HSE, which states that Ireland won't achieve its objective of 5% smoking incidence by 2025 but only by 2052 and underline the need for a change in the approach to tobacco control which takes into consideration e-cigarettes as part of the solution.::Explain what is happening in the UK, where smoking rates decreased drastically since e-cigarettes became mainstream. The UK and Ireland have identical tobacco control policies, except for the approach to e-cigarettes, which is open in the UK and very skeptical in Ireland. Ireland should follow the UK approach if it wants to accelerate the decline in smoking incidence.::Flag the DoH initiative on guidelines for the use of cocaine (launched on 18.07.2018) and how the Department managed to find time and resources to advise on the use of an illegal drug, while not investing any resources in research and guidelines on the use of e-cigarettes, which are a real tool that can help harm reduction in Ireland.::Highlight the conclusions of the House of Commons Science and Technology Committee report on e-cigarettes, which overwhelmingly concludes that not only are e-cigarettes substantially less harmful than traditional cigarettes but that they can be used to significantly reduce smoking rates.

Specific Details: Preliminary observations on the Employment Permits (Consolidation and Amendment) Bill 2019
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Preliminary observations on the Employment Permits (Consolidation and Amendment) Bill 2019
Intended Results: In the impending remuneration review, the Department may wish to consider extending the types of remuneration permissible to be taken into consideration, e.g. relocation bonuses, daily stipends, allowances etc::The Special Circumstances Permit is an opportunity for the Department to respond to situations that “fall between” the current system.  3.3.	It would be useful for the Department to engage with stakeholders as to what jobs might be considered to fall within this permit type.::The current position is that moving an employee to another group company amounts to a breach of the Acts.   Head 12 and Head 25 require further assessment.::The waiver of the 50:50 rule for sole employees is a very welcome development. It isn’t clear if this also applies for renewals, and we would suggest amending Head 26(15) to clarify the position.::The Society notes that Head 15 doesn’t appear to specifically exempt employments over a specified remuneration level from the Labour Market Needs Test.   It may be more appropriate to include that exemption in Head 15 rather than the regulations..::The new provision in Section 17 has the potential to cause issues when considering the interaction between atypical work permits and employment permits.::It isn’t apparent to us why the mere fact that an individual is obtaining a second employment should be a reason for refusal provided the individual meets all other requirements in respect of both applications, particularly where the individual is highly skilled.::It would be helpful if the permit process was revised slightly for applicants who already have a permit. One potential solution would be to extend the period for returning the original permit and making the issuing of the new permission conditional on the return of such permit.::Employees in possession of a critical skills employment permit cannot apply for a Stamp 4 letter until they have been employed for 21 months. However, it is taking a considerable period of time (up to 12 weeks) to receive support letters for Stamp 4 applications. This effectively means that the employee is in limbo until they receive their stamp 4 letter and obtain an appointment with the department, resulting in a risk that the employee will not get an appointment until after expiry  of permit

Lobbyist Name: Social Innovation Growth Fund Ireland Limited trading as Rethink Ireland.
Specific Details: A number of organisations that work in the youth mental health sector had particular concerns about the impact of COVID 19 on the mental health of children and young people in Ireland. Together we came up with  recommendations to address the issue. Our endgame is for those recommendations to be considered and/or to inform the steps the government takes to support young people’s mental health at this time. Rethink Jessica Curtis  is co-chair with Dr Shari McDaid.
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: A number of organisations that work in the youth mental health sector had particular concerns about the impact of COVID 19 on the mental health of children and young people in Ireland. Together we came up with  recommendations to address the issue. Our endgame is for those recommendations to be considered and/or to inform the steps the government takes to support young people’s mental health at this time. Rethink Jessica Curtis  is co-chair with Dr Shari McDaid.
Intended Results: Put in place additional capacity in early intervention services to support children and young people’s mental health to prevent recent and current distress becoming severe, longer-term mental health difficulties.
Lobbying Activities:
Letter sent 22nd July  on behalf of The Children and Young People’s Mental Health COVID-19 Coalition (Co-chaired by Rethink Ireland)
1)A clear strategy should be put in place to meet the need for talking therapies at primary care level,
2)Referral pathways to primary care psychology should be expanded and improved, 
3)Online primary care-level talking therapy services should be made available to all teenagers and young adults as soon as possible, 
4)A signposting tool should be developed to facilitate children and young people’s access to existing, quality information to support all areas of their life.
5)Resources should be allocated, including the scaling up of e-mental health infrastructure to (CAMHS) across community and acute settings to effectively meet existing and emerging mental health need.
6)The HSE should invest to expand the number of funded courses in educational and counselling psychology
7)The Mental Health Act 2001 should be amended protect the legal right of 16 and 17|Letter|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Jessica Curtis- Senior Fund Manager Rethink Ireland on behalf of  The Children and Young People’s Mental Health COVID-19 Coalition

Intended Results: Launch IFA initiative invitation to Minister::To highlight that, Connecting for Life, Ireland's National Strategy to Reduce Suicide 2015-2020 identified farmers as a vulnerable group at increased risk of suicidal behaviour. IFA is very concerned as the winter approaches and the uncertainty of the pandemic continues for the well-being of farmers and their families.::That research has showed that resilience training can help farmers identify realistic, practical wellness activities to better cope with the multitude of work stresses which they face on a daily basis.::To highlight taht IFA is developing a new initiative of resilience workshops for farmers in response to these concerns. DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: AOTI wrote to the Minister of State with Responsibility for Mental Health and Older People about a range of commitments regarding mental health and older people set out in the Programme for Government and in particular those relevant to the Occupational Therapy profession.

Lobbying Activities:
Specific commitments mentioned were:  
•	Continue the implementation of Sláintecare and wider reforms
•	Establish a national committee to ensure successful implementation of the new mental health policy Sharing the Vision 
•	Provide more occupational therapists to increase support to individuals with mental health concerns attending primary care services 
•	Introduce a statutory scheme to support older people to live in their own homes
•	Increase homecare hours and expand Community Intervention Teams
•	Maintain support for the Housing Adaptation Grant Scheme.|Letter|1

Specific Details: Public Health planning for Winter 2021 / 2022. NHI raised with the Ministers heightened concern within our health services arising from continued prevalence of Covid19 in our communities and the concerning impact this is having upon our health and social care sector. NHI requested meeting with both Minister Donnelly and Butler to discuss the winter plan and how best to protect residents and staff during another winter of Covid.
DPOs Lobbied: Stephen Donnelly|Minister|Department of Health::Mary Butler|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Public Health planning for Winter 2021 / 2022. NHI raised with the Ministers heightened concern within our health services arising from continued prevalence of Covid19 in our communities and the concerning impact this is having upon our health and social care sector. NHI requested meeting with both Minister Donnelly and Butler to discuss the winter plan and how best to protect residents and staff during another winter of Covid.
Intended Results: NHI requested an urgent meeting with the Ministers to discuss the winter plan for 2021/2022 as there needed to be a collaborative approach to insure everyone is best equipped as we head into a challenging winter period. Meeting would provide opportunity for NHI to inform of Covid19 challenges presented by nursing homes and requirement for collective plan to ensure residents are protected from virus and appropriate infection prevention control measures are in place and resourced.

Specific Details: Nursing Homes Support Scheme (Fair Deal) and Review of Pricing System for Long Term Residential Care Facilities
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|Minister of State|Department of Health::Stephen Donnelly|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Nursing Homes Support Scheme (Fair Deal) and Review of Pricing System for Long Term Residential Care Facilities
Intended Results: NHI critiqued and added observations following a correspondence from Minister Butler on the Nursing Home Support Scheme Pricing Mechanism Review. NHI presented to Minister the present scheme, as verified by independent analyses, is not commensurate with the reality of resident care needs.::The private and voluntary nursing home sector is experiencing a crisis due to the failings of the Fair Deal scheme to recognize the real costs of providing nursing home care. Substantive cost pressures are arising as a result of the implementation of ongoing intensified public health measures by nursing homes in order to safeguard residents from the impact of COVID 19. Intensified cost pressures are also being experienced arising from substantive increases in the cost base.

Specific Details: Presentation of NHI Staffing and Cost Pressures Analyses
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Presentation of NHI Staffing and Cost Pressures Analyses
Intended Results: Present to the State the extent and extremity of staffing and cost pressures being experienced by the private and voluntary nursing home sector. The State cannot continue to overlook the extremity of the pressures that present in meeting costs and recruiting and retaining staff. Requirement for engagement with NHI to address issues threatening the sustainability of nursing homes.
Lobbying Activities: NHI are asking the  State to recognise the realistic and true cost to provide nursing home care. Equivalent pay for staff providing equivalent care in the nursing home sector must become a reality under Fair Deal and represents a very legitimate and fair ask. Furthermore, it is imperative the scheme recognises the increasing cost pressures for the provision of nursing home care. Our representations are against a backdrop of Covid19 Nursing Homes Expert Panel recommendations and the very considerable rise in costs being incurred due to persistent inflation|Letter|1

Specific Details: Establishment of Strategic Workforce Advisory Group
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Establishment of Strategic Workforce Advisory Group
Intended Results: Representation to Minister for Older People Mary Butler to inform NHI welcome the creation of this critical group. However, NHI must express deep disappointment that neither the Private and Voluntary Nursing Home sector, nor the Homecare sector, have been invited to nominate a representative on the Advisory Group on matters which most directly impact upon them - recruitment of healthcare staff. NHI stated a representative should be nominated from our sector to sit on this advisory group.
Lobbying Activities: The terms of reference of this group state clearly that the group will examine the strategic workforce challenges in both publicly and privately provided front-line carer roles in home support and nursing homes, in order to “make recommendations for consideration by the relevant Minister or Ministers”. In spite of this focus on the Nursing Home and Homecare sectors within the terms of reference, direct membership and participation within the group from these sectors has been omitted.|Letter|1

Specific Details: Letter to Minister Butler re suggested wording for section 8(1)(b) of the proposed revised Mental Health Act. This follows grave concerns psychiatrists have around providing timely treatment and care to the small number of people with severe mental health crisis and illness who need treatment and support under the Act. The current proposed threshold is too high and will have the unintended consequence of potentially depriving those people of appropriate and required treatment.
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Letter to Minister Butler re suggested wording for section 8(1)(b) of the proposed revised Mental Health Act. This follows grave concerns psychiatrists have around providing timely treatment and care to the small number of people with severe mental health crisis and illness who need treatment and support under the Act. The current proposed threshold is too high and will have the unintended consequence of potentially depriving those people of appropriate and required treatment.
Intended Results: - That the Bil for an amended Mental Heath Act will include the suggested wording for section 8(1)(b).This wording (i) is more protective of patient rights (as it is simpler & clearer for patients, families, legal representatives, mental health professionals, tribunals, courts); (ii) it is more up-to-date (given that Ireland’s Expert Group Report on the revising the Act was drafted almost a decade ago); (iii) it is consistent with contemporary legislation other jurisdictions.

Specific Details: NHI wrote a letter to Minister Donnelly and Minister Butler informing them that NHI had lodged a formal State aid complaint with the European Commission on behalf of our members. Specific Details: Home Support Scheme
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Home Support Scheme
Intended Results: To acknowledge the work of the Minister of State for Health and that of the Department of Health in delivering the Nursing Home Support Scheme, a crucial scheme for farm families that provides financial assistance and support for loved ones who require long-term nursing home care.::The amendments to the legislation, including the 3-year cap for farm families introduced under your guidance have had a significant positive impact for farm families.::To propose a Home Support Scheme. IFA believes that, with the increasing scarcity of nursing home beds, particularly in rural Ireland, as well as the desire of older people to remain in their own homes, there is a strong necessity to introduce a Home Support Scheme.::Such a scheme could create a more inclusive, person-centred, and forward-thinking healthcare system. This aligns with the evolving needs and preferences of our ageing population, promoting a culture of care that prioritises individual well-being and autonomy.::To seek a meeting with the Minister of State for Health to discuss the development of a statutory Home Support Scheme to support people to live and be cared for in their home.::To highlight that the Programme for Government commits to 'introduce a statutory scheme to support people to live in their own homes, which will provide equitable access to high-quality, regulated home care'.::To emphasise that a key step in this process is to regulate home support services so that no matter where or how care is provided, service users can be assured that their provider meets minimum standards of quality.::To highlight the advantages of a Home Support Scheme that would play an important role in modern healthcare systems by providing essential care and assistance to individuals in the comfort of their own homes.::The significance of  implementing and maintaining a robust home support scheme cannot be stressed enough;::1. Aging Population::- With aging populations worldwide, there is a growing demand for long-term care services.::- A Home Support Scheme enables elderly individuals to age in place, preserving their independence and dignity.::2. Enhanced Quality of Life::- Home support services contribute to a higher quality of life by allowing individuals to remain in familiar surroundings.::- Personalised care plans cater to the unique needs and preferences of each individual, promoting overall wellbeing.::3. Cost-Effectiveness::- Home-based care is often more cost-effective than institutional care, such as nursing homes and hospitals.::- By preventing unnecessary hospital admissions or readmissions, a home support scheme helps to reduce healthcare expenditures.::4. Family and Community Support::- Home support services alleviate the burden on family caregivers, enabling them to balance caregiving responsibilities with other obligations.::- Individuals receiving home support remain connected to their communities, fostering social integration and support networks.::5. Timely and Flexible Care::- Home support services offer timely and flexible care, adapting to individuals' changing needs over time.::- This flexibility accommodates diverse schedules and preferences, ensuring that individuals receive the right level of care when they need it.::6. Preventative Health Measures::- Home support workers can implement preventative health measures, such as medication management and fall prevention strategies, reducing the risk of adverse health events.::To emphasise that it is important that the new Home Support Scheme will be integrated with other healthcare and social care services to provide person-centred care. It is also important that the planned statutory scheme be complimentary to, and supportive of, the provision of care by the families and other unpaid carers.::To highlight that it is important for everyone to have access to an affordable, universal, single-tiered healthcare system, and that the design of the new home support will aim to ensure that cost is not a barrier to accessing services. People should be supported to live at home and to receive the required care and support in their own home or as close to home as possible.::For vulnerable groups such as the elderly and those living with disabilities, reducing the use of residential care in favour of a 'home first' approach is beneficial. Keeping people in their homes should have benefits for patient health and wellbeing, and it may also serve to reduce the demand on long term residential care and acute hospital facilities.::To highlight that with the projected increase in our ageing population, it is necessary to prepare for the increasing demand for homecare and home support services in our communities.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Francie Gorman IFA President, Alice Doyle IFA Deputy President, Teresa Roche IFA Farm Family & Social Affairs Chair, Claire McGlynn IFA Policy Executive

Specific Details: Letter to Ministers Donnelly and Butler again seeking an urgent meeting to discuss and highlight serious concerns with aspects of the Mental Health Bill 2024 and required amendments needed to ensure it serves its purpose for those with serious mental illness requiring treatment.
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|Minister of State|Department of Health::Stephen Donnelly|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Letter to Ministers Donnelly and Butler again seeking an urgent meeting to discuss and highlight serious concerns with aspects of the Mental Health Bill 2024 and required amendments needed to ensure it serves its purpose for those with serious mental illness requiring treatment.
Intended Results: That the Department grant the meeting to explain and discuss the concerns and issues noted but also consider the well-thought-out workable solutions the College has for the relevant sections of the Bill to be amended. This is needed in advance of the department finalising its instructions to and for Government on amendments of the Bill.
Lobbying Activities: The Bill in its current form is, in effect, unworkable for doctors and patients and, under the legislation as proposed, psychiatrists, as specialist doctors, simply would not be able to provide the requisite treatment and care to the small number of those seriously unwell in our society with severe and serious symptoms of mental illness|Letter|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Dr Lorcan Martin and Dr Joanne Fegan

Specific Details: Post meeting letter and summary document outlining the issues, concerns and solutions discussed with officials of the Mental Health unit of the Department of Health on the current iteration on the mental health Bill 2024.
DPOs Lobbied: Mary Butler|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Post meeting letter and summary document outlining the issues, concerns and solutions discussed with officials of the Mental Health unit of the Department of Health on the current iteration on the mental health Bill 2024.
Intended Results: To provide the solutions to address those issues. They can be considered for amendments required and included with other amendments being prepared and required to improve the Mental Health Bill 2024 and ensure patients get the best possible individual focused treatment in a timely manner.
Lobbying Activities:
Following a meeting between several College members and staff at the Department of Health, this document was created and sent to the department. It highlights key areas of concern in the Mental Health Bill 2024. It also offer potential solutions in the following areas:

1. Consent to treatment
2. Definition of mental disorder
3. Psychosocial assessment (PSA) 
4. Regulations concerning care plans 
5. Powers of the review board
6. Inspection of all community mental health services, including CAMHS|Letter|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Dr Joanne Fegan and Dr Lorcan Martin
